Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Implementing AL-enhanced Machine-Learning for Advanced Electrochemical Manufacturing
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to demonstrate feasibility of machine-learning (ML)-guided experimental campaigns that predict, assess, and optimize electroorganic transformations with small experimental datasets. Companies across the chemical industry have pinpointed electrochemistry as a promising avenue for the implementation of more sustainable and energy-efficient manufacturing processes. However, the large cost and effort required in new process development hinders the implementation of electrochemical technologies. ML predictive algorithms can be a powerful tool to accelerate the development and optimization of more sustainable chemical processes, but repeatedly require large amounts of experimental data to train the models. These large datasets are often unavailable and expensive to obtain, which significantly limits the use of ML in the chemical industry. The project will advance future manufacturing by enabling the development of new and more sustainable chemical production routes using 50% less experiments, ultimately unlocking the manufacture of new molecules, medicines, and materials in societal applications. Moreover, by reducing the number of experiments required, the technology will significantly lower emissions and resource consumption in the industry.<br/><br/>The proposed project introduces a ML platform capable of guiding experimental campaigns and data collection to enable accurate predictions of reaction behavior with the smallest possible datasets. The approach relies on the combination of chemical engineering and ML knowledge to overcome the optimization limitations found within each field. It will be validated using the electrooxidation of p-methoxytoluene as a model reaction and will elucidate the fundamental limitations and strengths of ML predictive models capturing the complexity of physical systems with small datasets.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project demonstrated the feasibility of machine-learning (ML)-guided experimental campaigns that predict, assess, and optimize electroorganic transformations with small experimental datasets.

Companies across the chemical industry have pinpointed electrochemistry as a promising avenue for the implementation of more sustainable and energy-efficient manufacturing processes. However, the large cost and effort required in new process development through extensive experimentation hinders the implementation of electrochemical technologies.

Working at the intersection of ML and chemical engineering, we have developed, benchmarked, and validated ML predictive algorithms that accelerate the development and optimization of more sustainable electrochemical processes. We introduce a platform approach that can be leveraged from the earliest stages of chemical R&D, starting analysis with only 5 experiments or data points. The algorithms hereby developed were implemented in the optimization of a model organic electrosynthesis route, achieving up to 18% higher product yield using to 61-94% less experiments and resources than more traditional optimization campaigns. This is thus a technology that can enable up to 15 times faster development of new medicine, chemicals, and materials. In addition to massive cost and time savings, it can significantly lower emissions and resource consumption in industry.

The technology proved robust across variations in representativeness and size of the initial datasets. Moreover, the approach is designed to be reaction-agnostic, opening avenues for implementation of electrochemical technologies in multiple sectors of chemical manufacturing. This project elucidated the main advantages and limitations of ML predictive models capturing the complexity of physical systems with small data, and opens opportunities for subsequent R&D and commercialization efforts to ensure widespread adoption of the technology across chemical manufacturing.


Last Modified: 07/13/2022
Modified by: Daniela E Blanco

Companies across the chemical industry have pinpointed electrochemistry as a promising avenue for the implementation of more sustainable and energy-efficient manufacturing processes. However, the large cost and effort required in new process development through extensive experimentation hinders the implementation of electrochemical technologies. Working at the intersection of ML and chemical engineering, we have developed, benchmarked, and validated ML predictive algorithms that accelerate the development and optimization of more sustainable electrochemical processes. We introduce a platform approach that can be leveraged from the earliest stages of chemical R&D, starting analysis with only 5 experiments or data points. The algorithms hereby developed were implemented in the optimization of a model organic electrosynthesis route, achieving up to 18% higher product yield using to 61-94% less experiments and resources than more traditional optimization campaigns. This is thus a technology that can enable up to 15 times faster development of new medicine, chemicals, and materials. In addition to massive cost and time savings, it can significantly lower emissions and resource consumption in industry. The technology proved robust across variations in representativeness and size of the initial datasets. Moreover, the approach is designed to be reaction-agnostic, opening avenues for implementation of electrochemical technologies in multiple sectors of chemical manufacturing. This project elucidated the main advantages and limitations of ML predictive models capturing the complexity of physical systems with small data, and opens opportunities for subsequent R&D and commercialization efforts to ensure widespread adoption of the technology across chemical manufacturing.
